column1: Melo (Spanish pronunciation: [ˈmelo]) is the capital city of the Cerro Largo Department of north-eastern Uruguay. As of the census of 2011
column2: it is the ninth most populated city of the country.

column1: == Location ==
It is located at the center of the department
column2: on the intersection of Route 7 with Route 8
column3: 60 kilometres (37 mi) south of Aceguá and the border with Brazil. Other primary roads to the city are Route 26 and Route 44.

column1: == Geography ==
The stream Arroyo Conventos (a tributary of Tacuarí River) flows by the west limits of the city.
== History ==
It was founded on 27 June 1795 by Agustín de la Rosa
column2: an officer to the Spanish Empire. It was named after Pedro Melo de Portugal
column3: a Spanish colonial official of Portuguese royal ancestry.

column1: Given its proximity to some Portuguese colonies in Brazil
column5: was invaded by Portuguese forces in 1801
column8: Melo was officially declared capital of the department of Cerro Largo.

column2: the city square was renamed in honor of Manuel Oribe
column3: a former President of Uruguay and a political leader of the White Party (Partido Blanco)
column4: which brought to light the relations of this corner of the country with that National Movement (the vast majority of its inhabitants have belonged to that same political community).

column1: Melo had acquired the status of "Villa" (town) before the Independence of Uruguay. Its status was elevated to "Ciudad" (city) on 22 May 1895 by the Act of Ley Nº 2.3279. It was capital of one of the nine original departments of the Republic.
The historian J.C. Chasteen has discussed the place of Melo in the history of Uruguay in his book Heroes on Horseback: A Life and Times of the Last Gaucho Caudillos.

== Climate ==
Melo has a humid subtropical climate
column2: described by the Köppen climate classification as Cfa. Summers are warm (with hot days and cool nights) and winters are cool
column3: with frequent frosts and fog. The precipitation is evenly distributed throughout the year
column6: and the annual average temperature is 17 °C (63 °F).

column1: This city has the lowest recorded temperature in Uruguay
